title: Amazon Rainforest Expedition
tagline: Plan a mission to protect the lungs of the Earth while learning key English vocabulary.
summary: Join the PixelBird scientific crew on an English-first journey through the Amazon Rainforest. You will coordinate research camps, collaborate with Indigenous partners, and stop illegal logging to keep the canopy alive.
learningOutcomes: Explain the global importance of the Amazon Rainforest using persuasive academic English.
Discuss trade-offs between biodiversity, community trust, and funding with cause-and-effect connectors.
Write a donor briefing that summarises scientific evidence and community feedback in under 250 words.
Use ten advanced ecology terms correctly in spoken discussions and written reflections.

sections.heading: Why the Amazon matters
content: The Amazon Rainforest covers 5.5 million square kilometres across nine countries. It stores around 123 billion tonnes of carbon and produces moisture that feeds rain clouds across South America.
More than 30 million people live in the Amazon basin, including 350 Indigenous groups whose knowledge is essential to long-term conservation.

sections.heading: Mission objectives
content: Your expedition must balance science, community impact, and funding. Each decision in the mission scenarios influences three metrics: Biodiversity Health, Community Trust, and Field Budget.
You will present your recommendations in English to international donors and local community leaders.
points: Support local rangers with fair pay

sections.heading: Language focus
content: This course highlights strategic connectors such as "therefore", "as a result", and "meanwhile" to express complex relationships.
Vocabulary tasks reinforce collocations like "canopy cover", "carbon sink", and "community stewardship".
points: Summarise satellite data in plain English

sections.heading: Field notes in English
content: Each lesson includes ready-to-use note templates that help students describe animal sightings, rainfall, and community meetings.
Learners practise converting technical Portuguese or Spanish expressions into global English for international partners.

lessonPlan.title: Briefing and context
objectives: Activate prior knowledge about rainforest services in English.
Analyse satellite imagery captions and extract key verbs.
activities: Warm-up discussion: Students describe a recent environmental headline in two sentences.
Gallery walk: Learners rotate through mission posters, matching English keywords with visuals.
Listening focus: Play an interview clip and complete a note-taking template.

lessonPlan.title: Language lab
objectives: Practise hedging language when presenting uncertain data.
Co-create a shared glossary using collaborative writing tools.
activities: Mini-lesson on modal verbs for recommendations (should, could, might).
Team task: rewrite technical paragraphs into accessible English for donors.
Pronunciation clinic focusing on multi-syllable ecology terms.

lessonPlan.title: Decision lab
objectives: Apply vocabulary in mission scenarios that require strategic decisions.
Debate funding priorities using persuasive connectors.
activities: Role cards assign students as scientists, Indigenous leaders, or funders.
Simulation: Teams respond to rapid-fire mission updates and justify their choices.
Reflection journal: Learners summarise trade-offs using first conditional sentences.

project.title: Capstone: Amazon Impact Brief
project.description: Students craft a bilingual (English-first) impact brief that secures funding while respecting community priorities.
steps: Research: Gather statistics from credible sources and paraphrase them in English.
Community quotes: Translate two Indigenous testimonies into respectful English summaries.
Recommendation matrix: Compare three strategies with pros, cons, and expected results.
Pitch: Deliver a three-minute presentation using digital slides or an interactive poster.

game.title: Canopy Guardian Mission
game.intro: Make strategic decisions for four critical scenarios. Keep every metric above zero and reach a total impact score of 12 to succeed.

metrics.label: Biodiversity Health
metrics.description: Represents species protection and habitat quality.

metrics.label: Community Trust
metrics.description: Measures collaboration with Indigenous and local partners.

metrics.label: Field Budget
metrics.description: Tracks how wisely you invest limited resources.

rounds.title: Choose your base camp
rounds.scenario: You must establish a research base near a wildlife corridor threatened by logging.

options.label: Deploy a floating solar-powered lab
options.description: Expensive, but it avoids cutting new clearings and inspires students.
options.feedback: The floating lab becomes a local attraction and protects the riverbanks, but maintenance costs spike.

options.label: Repurpose an abandoned logging camp
options.description: Cheap option yet close to sensitive habitats.
options.feedback: You save money but must invest time repairing the damage and rebuilding trust with nearby villages.

options.label: Partner with a nearby village cooperative
options.description: Share revenue and hire local guides to monitor wildlife.
options.feedback: Community co-management speeds up data collection and everyone feels represented.

rounds.title: Respond to illegal logging
rounds.scenario: Night drones spot chainsaws along a protected border. How do you react?

options.label: Finance rapid-response ranger patrols
options.description: Send trained rangers with satellite phones and legal support.
options.feedback: The patrol deters loggers and documents evidence for authorities, but it eats into your budget.

options.label: Launch a social-media awareness blitz
options.description: Create English videos showing the damage and calling for action.
options.feedback: The videos go viral and empower local youth, yet the loggers move to a new site.

options.label: Buy the timber to halt the operation
options.description: An emergency purchase that stops chainsaws instantly but sets a precedent.
options.feedback: You stop the cutting, but financiers question the long-term cost.

rounds.title: Design an education programme
rounds.scenario: Teachers ask for English lessons with climate science vocabulary.

options.label: Broadcast bilingual radio classes
options.description: Partner with community radio to deliver lessons across villages.
options.feedback: Radio shows strengthen trust and inspire new forest guardians.

options.label: Develop a mobile learning app
options.description: High-tech and trackable but requires smartphones and data.
options.feedback: Students enjoy the gamified lessons, yet connectivity gaps exclude remote learners.

options.label: Fund teacher training workshops
options.description: Invite Indigenous educators to co-create curriculum in English and local languages.
options.feedback: Workshops blend ancestral knowledge with new science vocabulary, motivating entire schools.

rounds.title: Restore a degraded area
rounds.scenario: A fire damaged 120 hectares. You must propose a recovery plan to donors.

options.label: Seed native trees using drones
options.description: Fast deployment but limited species diversity.
options.feedback: The drones impress donors and stabilise soil quickly, though the forest remains young.

options.label: Create community-run nurseries
options.description: Empower families to cultivate seedlings and track survival rates.
options.feedback: Families plant diverse species and share success stories in English and Indigenous languages.

options.label: Study natural regeneration
options.description: Collect long-term data before intervening, conserving funds.
options.feedback: Patience pays off as new species emerge, and the saved funds finance future expeditions.

quiz.question: What is a wildlife corridor?
choices: A river where scientists build dams
A connected route that animals use to migrate safely
A storage building for expedition equipment
quiz.answer: A connected route that animals use to migrate safely
quiz.explanation: Wildlife corridors allow species to travel between habitats without crossing dangerous human-made barriers.

quiz.question: Which expression best describes "community trust"?
choices: Confidence between partners working toward the same goal
Money reserved for emergencies
A type of protected rainforest tree
quiz.answer: Confidence between partners working toward the same goal
quiz.explanation: Community trust reflects how confident local partners feel about collaborating on conservation projects.

quiz.question: What does the verb "to restore" mean in the context of ecology?
choices: To remove every tree
To return an ecosystem to a healthier state
To translate documents
quiz.answer: To return an ecosystem to a healthier state
quiz.explanation: Restoration describes actions that help a damaged ecosystem recover its structure and functions.

quiz.question: Which phrase correctly uses the term "carbon sink"?
choices: The forest acts as a carbon sink that absorbs emissions from nearby cities.
Rangers carbon sink their uniforms after patrols.
Carbon sink describes the colour of the soil in the dry season.
quiz.answer: The forest acts as a carbon sink that absorbs emissions from nearby cities.
quiz.explanation: A carbon sink is any system that captures and stores carbon dioxide instead of releasing it into the atmosphere.

quiz.question: When presenting baseline data, which sentence is most precise?
choices: We kind of saw some birds maybe in the north.
Initial surveys recorded 32 scarlet macaw nests along the northern corridor.
Birds were everywhere.
quiz.answer: Initial surveys recorded 32 scarlet macaw nests along the northern corridor.
quiz.explanation: Baseline data should use clear numbers and specific locations to support evidence-based decisions.

title: Coral Reef Rescue
tagline: Use English to plan community-led reef restoration in the Caribbean.
summary: Bleaching events threaten fish populations and tourism. Learn the vocabulary of marine science and lead a rapid response that balances ecology with local livelihoods.
learningOutcomes: Describe the coral bleaching process with accurate scientific vocabulary.
Coach tourism staff in English so they can brief visitors on reef-safe behaviour.
Compare three restoration methods using comparative adjectives and persuasive structures.
Deliver a data-driven update that invites international partners to collaborate.

sections.heading: The science
content: Coral reefs cover less than 1% of the ocean floor yet support 25% of marine species. When ocean temperatures rise, corals expel the algae that feed them, creating bleaching events.
Community action in English connects local dive teams with international researchers who can provide funding and equipment.

sections.heading: Mission focus
content: Coordinate a reef restoration hub, teach eco-tourism phrases, and protect the livelihoods that depend on healthy coral.
Students review authentic dive logs, weather alerts, and donor emails to practise real-life comprehension.
points: Train guides to brief visitors in English
Track coral health with open-data tools

sections.heading: Language focus
content: Lessons model useful frames such as "according to the data", "in contrast", and "to mitigate the impact".
Pronunciation drills target key terms like "polyps", "sedimentation", and "sustainable charter

sections.heading: Community storytelling
content: Learners practise interviewing fishers, dive instructors, and youth leaders, then translate their quotes into engaging English narratives.
The module includes templates for writing newsletters and social media updates that celebrate progress.

vocabulary.example: The marine park set new rules for charter operators to protect the reef.

Identify cause-and-effect language related to climate stress.
activities: Map jigsaw: Teams decode different data layers and teach their findings to classmates.

Terminology cards: Students match key phrases with icons and gestures.

Role-play difficult conversations with visitors who break reef rules.

Feedback carousel: Partners exchange scripts and highlight effective vocabulary.

Evaluate partner proposals based on budget, impact, and community support.

project.title: Capstone: Reef Recovery Dashboard
project.description: Learners compile a digital dashboard that tracks coral health, visitor education, and funding milestones.
steps: Collect: Gather metrics from monitoring logs, tourism surveys, and budget sheets.
Translate: Rewrite technical data into clear English headlines and captions.
Storyboard: Organise updates into a one-page dashboard using icons and charts.
Present: Deliver a stand-up meeting update with calls to action for partners.

game.title: Reef Rapid-Response
game.intro: Navigate three urgent decisions to keep coral polyps alive. Reach a score of 10 or more for a thriving reef.

metrics.label: Reef Resilience

rounds.title: Collect bleaching data
rounds.scenario: You have 48 hours to measure water temperatures and coral colour.

options.label: Recruit snorkelers as citizen scientists
options.description: Provide waterproof vocabulary cards and data sheets.
options.feedback: Families feel empowered, and international NGOs share your reports widely.

options.label: Rent a thermal drone
options.description: Fast results but high daily cost.
options.feedback: Accurate maps guide divers, though your budget shrinks.

options.label: Wait for a university lab
options.description: Free analysis but results arrive late.
options.feedback: The delay frustrates fishers, even if the data is precise.

rounds.title: Scale coral nurseries
rounds.scenario: Storm season approaches and young corals need safe habitats.

options.label: Install rope nurseries with volunteer divers
options.description: Affordable, requires strong teamwork and English safety briefings.
options.feedback: Tourists join weekend restoration dives and donate gear.

options.label: Deploy 3D-printed reef structures
options.description: High-tech modules offer instant habitat but shipping is costly.
options.feedback: Fish colonise quickly, yet you must secure new sponsors.

options.label: Pause nurseries and invest in school programmes
options.description: Teach marine vocabulary first, then return to the water.
options.feedback: Students organise clean-up days, but coral recovery slows.

rounds.title: Manage eco-tourism
rounds.scenario: A cruise company offers to bring 400 visitors per month.

options.label: Limit visitors and raise prices
options.description: Fewer people but better guides and reef-friendly briefings.
options.feedback: Small groups respect the reef and spend more on local crafts.

options.label: Accept the offer with strict rules
options.description: Invest in floating barriers and English signage.
options.feedback: Revenue grows, yet snorkelling pressure stresses the coral.

options.label: Reject mass tourism entirely
options.description: Focus on research partnerships instead.
options.feedback: Scientists applaud the decision, though some guides lose short-term income.

quiz.question: What is coral bleaching?
choices: A celebration where reefs are painted white
A stress response where corals lose the algae that feed them
A technique to clean ship hulls
quiz.answer: A stress response where corals lose the algae that feed them
quiz.explanation: Bleaching occurs when high temperatures force corals to expel symbiotic algae, turning them pale and weak.

quiz.question: What does "eco-tourism briefing" mean?
choices: A business meeting to sell cruise tickets
Instructions that teach visitors how to protect the environment during their trip
A radio programme about local sports
quiz.answer: Instructions that teach visitors how to protect the environment during their trip
quiz.explanation: An eco-tourism briefing gives travellers clear guidelines for respectful and safe environmental behaviour.

quiz.question: Which option best defines "reef resilience"?
choices: The number of boats visiting a reef
The ability of coral ecosystems to recover from stress
The price of scuba equipment
quiz.answer: The ability of coral ecosystems to recover from stress
quiz.explanation: Resilience is the capacity of the reef to bounce back after storms, heat waves, or pollution.

quiz.question: Which sentence uses "runoff" correctly?
choices: We runoff the volunteers after training.
Farm runoff carried fertiliser into the lagoon and damaged the coral.
The reef runoffs tourists every weekend.
quiz.answer: Farm runoff carried fertiliser into the lagoon and damaged the coral.
quiz.explanation: Runoff refers to water that flows over land and transports sediments or pollutants into the sea.

quiz.question: Why is an underwater nursery important?
choices: It stores extra diving tanks for tourists.
It gives young corals a safe place to grow before being transplanted onto the reef.
It is a hotel for marine scientists.
quiz.answer: It gives young corals a safe place to grow before being transplanted onto the reef.
quiz.explanation: Nurseries protect coral fragments, allowing them to reach a healthy size before replanting in damaged areas.
